Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: Documenting Diversity in the Apex of the Coral Triangle: Inventory of Philippine Marine Biodiversity
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will document a suspected peak in marine animal diversity in the Earth?s most diverse marine realm. Investigators from the California Academy of Sciences (CAS), in collaboration with numerous other US and Philippine institutions, will document the kinds of marine organisms in the Coral Triangle of Southeast Asia, focusing on the "center of the center of biodiversity," the Verde Island Passage (VIP) of Luzon, Philippines. Researchers will assess the extreme biodiversity across the VIP to determine species distributions, analyze genetic diversity among species, and discover new species, including in the Twilight Zone, accessible through advanced underwater technology that allows exploration at depths below those reached with traditional scuba diving.

The project will establish crucial baseline information on biodiversity at key VIP localities before further impact of global climate change and human development activities. Results will inform regional and global conservation and management policies, and engage the public in protecting coral reef communities integral to oceanic and human health. Data and collections will be preserved and cataloged, and will be available for study into the future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the course of the project we have documented the existence of more than 400 new species of marine life in the VIP, further providing evidence that the Verde Island Passage is the Center of the Center of marine diversity. Evidence supporting this idea comes from studying a wide range of taxa, including marine algae, sponges, soft corals, hard corals, crustaceans (amphipods, decapods and barnacles), snalis and slugs, segmented worms, sand dollars and sea urchins and fishes. The exploration of the twilight zone was also highly successful and included deep dives to 150 m depth over three field seasons. Many new species resulted from these explorations and are documented in seveal recent publications. More than 50 scientific papers and one popular field guide to the nudibranchs of the Indo-Pacific. The explorations from the eastern boundary of the Verde Island Passage (VIP) around Romblon Island yielded new information about the diversity of the entire VIP. Speciesnot found in other portions of the VIP from prior studies were found in Romblon, including many novel taxa. All of these data further corroborate the previous work in the western and central VIP that suggests that diversity is highest in the central VIP, but unique species are represented in each portion of the VIP. Several in depth studies, such as the paper by Ong, Hallas and Gosliner (2016) demonstrate great evolutionary diversity represented in the VIP, in addition to high species richness.

One of the major other achievements of the this project was the updating of theCalifornia Academy of Sciences' coral reef display with the addition of the Twilight Zone exhibit and the updating of the Philippine conservation heros voices sections. This updates have now been visited by more than 3 million visitors. Other outcomes include advances in animal husbandry (see Shepard et al. 2017 attached) and the sharing of new animal husbandry and coral spawning techniques with Philippine partners. Our outreach activities with students, teachers and community members have reached more than 3000-4000 Filipinos and tens of millions of web impressions and visits to the various Academy webpages featuring this work.

More than 200 staff of the Philippine Bureau of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources (BFAR) and the National Fisheries Research and Development Institute (NFRDI) have participated in advanced training workshops focusing on taxonomy, web resoures, and collections protocols. Over the course of the award, twentyfour graduate students have participated in the project, include students from SanFrancisco State University (6), University of California Santa Cruz (1), Old Dominion University (2), University of the Philippines (7), De la Salle University (4), Silliman University (4). Three postdocs have participated in field and laboratory research. Eleven undergraduates funded by REU 1358680 have undertaken projects working on material collected during the field seasons for this project. During Summer, 2017, two staff members of NFRDI (Salvacio Ferrer and Luz Romena) participated in the Academy's Summer Systematics Institute and undertook individual research projects under the mentorship of an Academy mentor. One project focused on developing coral rearing techniques while the second project involved training in developent of IUCN redlist data. Beginning in the Fall of 2017, Joseph Comendador, Curator of Sponges at the Philippine National Museum. began his Master's program at San Francisco State University under the direction of PIs Gosliner and Mooi.

The richest areas we are finding clearly warrant increased conservation status and many unique habitats are generally not well preserved. We are confidentthat these studies will inform conservation priorities in the region. Our efforts to communicate this need have clearly gotten traction and local and national agencies in the Philippines appear receptive to increasing support for conservation. Multiple and protracted interaction with Philippine scientific, academic, conservation and governmental agencies have built a reputation of trust and increased receptivity for recommendations being put forth that call for a more effective sustainable use of local resources.

As part of this project, CoPIMooi launched a biodiversity module under the Khan Academy that has received several million views. Many examples come from the biodiversity work of this module. https://www.khanacademy.org/partnercontent/casbiodiversity. Another aspect of this project was the launch of a Philippine Biodiversity Project that incorporates data from our surveys, but also includes citizen science contributions from around the world. This project now includes almost 4000 observations of more than 1600 species from the Philippines. https://www.inaturalist.org/projects/philippinesbiodiversity

This project has made biodiversity data on the largest collection of Philippine marine biodiversity unviersally available through our search portal to study marine biodiversity. This is particularly valuable to our Philippine colleagues who do not have these informational resources available to them other than through this data base. http://researcharchive.calacademy.org/research/izg/iz_coll_db/index.asp
